name: Viktor Bergman
role: Supporting character - Elderly resident resisting biometrics on principle
core_wound: Lived through the Swedish registry controversy; watched institutions betray privacy promises before
wants: To maintain autonomy and privacy in his final years; to not be forced out of his home
needs: To find allies and realize his individual resistance matters
voice_markers: Quiet determination - doesn't argue, just states facts
Gentle irony - 'How convenient' said with dry precision
contradiction: Fears being seen as senile or paranoid but has the clearest view of what's happening; wants to fight back but feels too old to matter
knowledge_state: Lives alone in Turning Torso since his wife died (building was her dream)
Refuses all biometric enrollment - uses keycard and PIN only
Experiences frequent 'service issues' - elevator skips his floor, packages misdelivered, temperature problems
Keeps meticulous written records but doesn't know what to do with them

relationships.Saga_Lindström: Cautious kinship - both experiencing the same pattern
relationships.Erik_Månsson: Politely formal; knows Erik sees him as stubborn old man
relationships.Aisha_Osman: Reminds him of his granddaughter; sad she can't see the problem

physical_description: Precise posture, always wears watch (analog), carries a physical newspaper, tired eyes but sharp mind
background: Worked on infrastructure projects in the 1980s-90s, saw how data systems could be misused, widower, stays in apartment for memories
